Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an EEG-NIRs Bimodal Neural Signal Recording System

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant supports the acquisition of a neural recording system that integrates electroencephalography (EEG) and near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRs) together to provide bimodal data collection and analysis. The acquisition of this system enables faculty researchers across Biomedical & Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and Neuropsychology fields to work together and develop multidisciplinary research and educational activities. Multiple research projects are proposed to investigate fundamental challenges in EEG-NIRs bimodal signal acquisition and its widespread applications in healthcare, medical instrument, and brain computer interface. Graduate and undergraduate students, including minorities, will participate in the proposed research projects. Widener University is located in Chester, Pennsylvania, which has a large population from underrepresented groups and undergoing significant economic depression in the last decades. The researchers will work with two local educational programs to involve a group of middle/high school students over 95% of whom are from underrepresented groups, inspiring them to pursue college education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.

The goal of this grant is to acquire a BrainVision EEG-NIRs bimodal neural recording system that integrates a 32-channel BrainVision active channel amplifier EEG and a 32-channel NIRScout NIRs together. EEG is widely used to measure neural activity with a high temporal resolution but poor spatial specificity. NIRs is a noninvasive optical imaging technique that measures concentration changes of deoxygenated hemoglobin and oxygenated hemoglobin during brain activity in superficial layers of the human cortex. NIRs can measure metabolic changes associated with the neural activity with a higher spatial resolution than EEG, and this has prompted the effort to combine NIRs and EEG together to explore complementary information to each other. The bimodal system will be use for the development of a bimodal brain computer interface, computer-aided diagnosis and treatment of symptom recurrence after Chiari malformation surgery, and early diagnosis of sports-related concussion. The NIRs device will also be used to quantitatively evaluate a novel cooling device for targeted brain hypothermia, and to develop novel techniques to measure the flow distribution of a new hemodialysis machine. The system and associated research will advance our understanding of potential benefits from the combination of EEG and NIRs on different application fields. The study of data characteristics under the individual and combined modalities will generate new findings of data complexity, feature stationarity, and inter-modality interference. Novel data processing methods will be developed to perform artifacts removal, information fusion, adaptive learning and classification, and functional network mapping and dynamic modeling. The research projects will generate quantitative results to justify the expected improvement, and provide an extensible platform for future development of multimodal neuroimaging systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A 32-channel electroencephalogram (EEG) device and a 32-channel near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRs) were acquired to build a bimodal neural signal recording system. EEG can detect electrical activity in brain using small electrodes attached to scalp. It has been widely used for the diagnosis of epilepsy and other brain disorders. NIRs is an optical imaging technique that can measure metabolic changes associated with neural activities in superficial layers of the human cortex. EEG can provide a high temporal sampling rate with a poor spatial resolution. Compared to EEG, NIRs has a relatively low temporal resolution but a higher spatial resolution. This has prompted the effort to integrate EEG and NIRs together to explore complementary information from each other.

The EEG-NIRs bimodal system is installed in the Medical Imaging and Brain Computer Interface Laboratory, the first research laboratory focusing on neuroimaging and applications at Widener University. There are no medical school and hospitals affiliated with Widener University, and a frequent use of a bulky and expensive neuroimaging scanner, such as a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT) scanner, for research purposes is not realistic. The requested instrument is cost-effective but an ideal alternative option to MRI or CT. It allows investigators from different schools/colleges at Widener (College of Arts and Sciences, School of Engineering, and School of Human Service Professions) to perform single- and dual-mode sensing of brain or other tissues and conduct multidisciplinary research in different areas. Multiple research projects have been initiated using the acquired instrument, including the development of a bimodal brain computer interface, study of Chiari malformation postoperative symptom recurrence, computer-aided diagnosis and treatment evaluation of sports-related concussion, noninvasive measure of dialysis flow distribution, and efficiency evaluation of tissue cooling devices. Initial data acquisition experiments have been performed to collect EEG and NIRs data from a few experimental participants following the experimental protocols reviewed and approved by the Widener Institutional Review Board. More experiments will be performed as planned in these research projects. Research findings from these projects will advance our understanding of potential benefits and challenges from each sensing modality and the combination of them in different application fields.

The acquired instrument has a positive impact on research and educational activities at Widener. First, it augments our imaging capabilities from single-mode to dual-mode, and enables the faculty and student investigators to develop leading-edge research projects that could not be considered before. Second, it allows faculty and student researchers from different disciplines to work together and develop multidisciplinary research projects in emerging technology fields. Third, new courses and training programs can be developed based upon the instrument. Fourth, the faculty and student researchers from different backgrounds are working together, promoting academic diversity and broad participation. Finally, the main campus of Widener is located in Chester, Pennsylvania. Chester is one of six U.S. cities with a large population from underrepresented groups and undergoing significant economic depression within the last decades. The requested instrument and associated research projects will provide opportunities for Widener’s education and public outreach to broad audiences in Chester and surrounding communities. The investigators are working with the university administration to develop outreach educational programs that aims to inspire local middle and high school students to pursue college education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.
